description: A micro-lesson that makes Falafel: The Middle East's Contested Treasure usable.

hook.text: Israel, Egypt, Lebanon, and Palestine all claim falafel as their national food. The argument is fierce.

buildup.text: Falafel likely originated in Egypt as ta'ameya â€” made from fava beans, not chickpeas, by Coptic Christians.

discovery.text: As it spread north, chickpeas replaced fava beans. Lebanon, Syria, and Palestine each developed distinct versions.

twist.text: Israel adopted falafel post-1948, sparking 'food appropriation' debates that continue to this day.

climax.text: Regardless of ownership, falafel is the world's most popular street food â€” sold on every inhabited continent.

punchline.text: Everyone fights over who invented it. Everyone agrees it's perfect.
